BIO

After studying audio engineering at Columbia College, I became an intern at a post-production house, and later, I went on to manage a recording studio. Within the next few years, though, the music industry took a severe downturn. Around that time, I decided to leave my job at the studio, and began to search for my next passion.

Taking a friend's advice, I started learning how to code. In no time, I fell in love with it, and have been learing how to improve as a developer ever since. Thankfully, the same skill set that I had began cultivating as a studio manager/recording engineer (troubleshooting difficult problems by paying close attention to the details, thoroughly documenting pertinent information, thinking things through creatively, and working with a team toward a common goal) came in handy.

In addition to programming, I love vintage gaming, mechanical keyboards, film, synthesizers, and most of all, my two dogs.
